verses.text: For the kingdom of heaven is like a master of a house who went out early in the morning to hire laborers for his vineyard.
verses.comment: Jesus begins with a parable, likening the kingdom to a vineyard – a symbol often used for God's people in the Old Testament. This sets the stage for teaching about divine generosity and the nature of the kingdom.

verses.text: And when he had agreed with the laborers for a denarius a day, he sent them into his vineyard.
verses.comment: A denarius was a common wage for a day’s labor. The master’s agreement is just, reflecting God’s faithfulness to His promises.

verses.text: And going out about the third hour, he saw others standing in the marketplace idle.
verses.comment: The third hour is around 9 a.m. The master continually seeks workers, symbolizing God's persistent call.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'You also go into the vineyard, and whatever is right I will give you.' So they went.
verses.comment: The wage is not specified, signifying trust in the master's fairness; a subtle allusion to salvation being a gift, beyond strict human measure.

verses.text: Again he went out about the sixth and the ninth hour and did the same.
verses.comment: Sixth hour (noon) and ninth (3 p.m.): the repeated invitation illustrates God's continued outreach to all, regardless of timing.

verses.text: And about the eleventh hour he went out and found others standing, and he said to them, 'Why are you standing here idle all day?'
verses.comment: The eleventh hour (5 p.m.) is near day's end; even latecomers are welcomed, a demonstration of divine mercy and inclusivity.

verses.text: They said to him, 'Because no one has hired us.' He said to them, 'You also go into the vineyard.'
verses.comment: No one excluded; the master’s generous invitation foreshadows the openness of the kingdom to all who respond.

verses.text: And when evening came, the owner of the vineyard said to his foreman, 'Call the laborers and pay them their wages, beginning with the last, then going to the first.'
verses.comment: Reversal of order hints at the kingdom’s values, echoing Jesus’ teaching that the last will be first.

verses.text: And when those hired about the eleventh hour came, each of them received a denarius.
verses.comment: Equal pay for latecomers highlights God’s grace, challenging human notions of fairness.

verses.text: Now when those hired first came, they thought they would receive more, but each of them also received a denarius.
verses.comment: Expectation of greater reward by those who worked longest—an allegory for the dangers of entitlement before God.

verses.text: And on receiving it, they grumbled against the master of the house,
verses.comment: Echoes of Israel's complaints in the wilderness; human hearts often resist divine generosity.

verses.text: Saying, 'These last worked only one hour, and you have made them equal to us who have borne the burden of the day and the heat.'
verses.comment: The complaint uncovers the tension between justice and mercy—a running theme throughout Scripture.

verses.text: But he answered one of them, 'Friend, I am doing you no wrong. Did you not agree with me for a denarius?'
verses.comment: The master’s response affirms his right to be generous; aligns with God’s sovereignty and free gift of grace.

verses.text: 'Take what is yours and go. I choose to give to this last as I give to you.'
verses.comment: God’s benevolence does not diminish what He gives each person—an invitation to rejoice in others’ blessings.

verses.text: 'Am I not allowed to do what I wish with what belongs to me? Or is your eye evil because I am good?'
verses.comment: The ‘evil eye’ is a Hebrew expression signifying envy. God’s goodness transcends human comparison.

verses.text: So the last will be first, and the first last.
verses.comment: A summary of the parable's reversal—the kingdom operates by supernatural grace, not merit.

verses.text: And as Jesus was going up to Jerusalem, he took the twelve aside and said to them on the way,
verses.comment: Jesus now predicts His passion, taking His disciples aside—a sign of His intimate relationship and forthcoming fulfillment of prophecy.

verses.text: 'See, we are going up to Jerusalem. And the Son of Man will be delivered over to the chief priests and scribes, and they will condemn him to death'
verses.comment: ‘Son of Man’ recalls Daniel’s prophecy. Jesus foretells His rejection and death—underscoring His self-identification as Messiah and fulfillment of Scripture.

verses.text: 'and deliver him over to the Gentiles to be mocked and flogged and crucified, and on the third day he will be raised.'
verses.comment: Prediction of crucifixion and resurrection: explicit claim of future vindication, showing both Christ’s foreknowledge and divinity.

verses.text: Then the mother of the sons of Zebedee came to him with her sons, and kneeling before him, she asked for something from him.
verses.comment: Kneeling is a sign of reverence, as seen throughout Scripture; a subtle sign of Jesus’ authority.

verses.text: He said to her, 'What do you want?' She said to him, 'Say that these two sons of mine are to sit, one at your right hand and one at your left, in your kingdom.'
verses.comment: Request for seats of honor in Jesus' kingdom recalls messianic prophecy; connects to royal authority.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'You do not know what you are asking. Are you able to drink the cup that I am about to drink?' They said to him, 'We are able.'
verses.comment: ‘Cup’ symbolizes suffering. Jesus points to participation in His passion, a call to spiritual endurance and sacrifice.

verses.text: He said to them, 'You will drink my cup, but to sit at my right hand and at my left is not mine to grant, but it is for those for whom it has been prepared by my Father.'
verses.comment: Jesus delegates this authority to the Father, affirming a mysterious cooperation in the divine plan, and pointing toward the ongoing work of God through history.

verses.text: And when the ten heard it, they were indignant at the two brothers.
verses.comment: A glimpse of rivalry and misunderstanding among the disciples, highlighting the need for humility and unity.

verses.text: But Jesus called them to him and said, 'You know that the rulers of the Gentiles lord it over them, and their great ones exercise authority over them.'
verses.comment: Jesus contrasts earthly leadership with the kingdom’s humble service; teaching on the sanctity of serving others.

verses.text: 'It shall not be so among you. But whoever would be great among you must be your servant,'
verses.comment: True greatness is found in service—a theme modeled by Christ and later exemplified by the apostles and bishops.

verses.text: 'and whoever would be first among you must be your slave,'
verses.comment: Complete self-giving is the hallmark of leadership in the kingdom; echoes Jesus' own mission.

verses.text: 'even as the Son of Man came not to be served but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many.'
verses.comment: Jesus identifies Himself as the suffering servant of Isaiah; His sacrificial death is a ransom, a key doctrine underscoring His divinity and saving mission.

verses.text: And as they went out from Jericho, a great crowd followed him.
verses.comment: Jericho, a significant city, is the setting for the following miracle, gathering public attention to Jesus.

verses.text: And behold, two blind men sitting by the roadside, when they heard that Jesus was passing by, cried out, 'Lord, have mercy on us, Son of David!'
verses.comment: ‘Son of David’ is a messianic title, affirming Jesus' royal lineage and authority to heal, as prophesied.

verses.text: The crowd rebuked them, telling them to be silent, but they cried out all the more, 'Lord, have mercy on us, Son of David!'
verses.comment: Persistence in calling Jesus 'Lord' and 'Son of David' reflects deep faith and recognition of His authority, supporting a high Christology.

verses.text: And Jesus stopped and called them, and said, 'What do you want me to do for you?'
verses.comment: Jesus directly engages them, modeling personal concern and responsiveness.

verses.text: They said to him, 'Lord, let our eyes be opened.'
verses.comment: Their request is simple, but the title ‘Lord’ points to their recognition of Jesus' divine power.

verses.text: And moved with compassion, Jesus touched their eyes, and immediately they received their sight and followed him.
verses.comment: Jesus’ healing miracles fulfill prophetic signs of the Messiah; their immediate discipleship points toward spiritual and physical restoration as works of Christ’s kingdom.
